title: Win required to ruin Sam Allardyce’s party
text:
Second-bottom and without a win, Dick Advocaat didn’t really want to keep his job over the summer, and the way the Black Cats have been playing, you can see why. 
But new managers have the habit of instantly turning a club’s fortunes around. 
All of a sudden players are fighting harder for their place in the team and there is, of course, also a breath of fresh air about a new 
appointment, a sense of optimism, especially so early on in the season. 
Big Sam won his first games at both Newcastle and Blackburn, although he lost to Cardiff first time out with West Ham. 
Earlier this week, Pulis praised Allardyce for his impact at Upton Park, claiming Slaven Bilic is now ‘reaping the rewards’ of what his former manager achieved. 
But he will desperately want to spoil Allardyce’s party on Saturday, and after that dreadful performance away at Crystal Palace hanging over the club for two weeks, the Baggies boss will be eager to get his team out onto the pitch. Paul Lambert (left) and Sam Allardyce (right) 
Not only would handing Sunderland their first win of the season add to the pressure on Pulis, it would also drag Albion within two points of the bottom three. 
The Palace game sparked a furious response from fans, but it wasn’t so much the result as the manner of defeat that angered them. 
Setting up so defensively away has served Pulis well this season, and Yannick Bolasie’s header and Yohan Cabaye’s penalty are the only goals Albion have conceded on their travels so far. 
In contrast, Pulis’ men have picked up just one point in four games at The Hawthorns, but there is the feeling that the home faithful want to see a performance with attacking intent tomorrow as well as a victory. Two players that could add some drive going forwards are wingers Callum McManaman and Serge Gnabry. 
Gnabry curled a stunning goal into the top corner for Germany’s under-21s against the Faroe Islands earlier this week, and with James Morrison a doubt, he or McManaman could feature. 
Sunderland fans may be more focused on the other wing, where James McClean is likely to start his first game against his former club since criticising them in the way they handled his decision not to wear a poppy on an embroidered shirt in 2012. 
“They didn’t understand,” said McClean earlier this year. 
“To them, I was disrespecting their country, disrespecting their fallen heroes, disrespecting their culture. I was getting booed every touch. 
“When I asked to be allowed to speak about it, I was told that that was a bad idea, not to say anything and let it blow over. 
“So it was kind of brushed under the table and I felt that that was more for the club’s benefit than mine.” What do you think? Log in and start commenting 
Blowing hot and cold for Albion this season, McClean could use a match-winning performance at The Hawthorns and will be spurred on by his history with the North East side. 
Although Albion haven’t won any of the past three meetings between the two teams, drawing both league games last year and losing the one before that, their record against Sunderland in the Premier League is fantastic. 
Albion won seven and drew one of the eight games before those last three, and in the last ten meetings, have lost just once. More on this story:
